content.title: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
content.summary: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) encompasses a heterogeneous group of lymphoid malignancies arising from B cells (85%), T cells (15%), or NK cells (<1%). Unlike Hodgkin lymphoma, NHL lacks Reed-Sternberg cells and tends to spread noncontiguously. NHL ranges from indolent (follicular lymphoma) to highly aggressive (Burkitt lymphoma), with treatment and prognosis varying dramatically by subtype.
key_points: Heterogeneous group of >60 distinct lymphoma subtypes
B-cell NHL (85%): DLBCL most common aggressive; follicular most common indolent
T-cell NHL (15%): generally more aggressive with poorer outcomes
Spreads noncontiguously (unlike HL); often presents in advanced stage
R-CHOP is standard for DLBCL; watch-and-wait for asymptomatic indolent NHL
Many novel therapies: CAR-T, bispecifics, targeted agents
content.statement: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a diverse group of lymphoid neoplasms arising predominantly from B cells, classified by cell of origin and clinical behavior (indolent vs aggressive), with treatment ranging from observation to intensive chemoimmunotherapy or CAR-T cell therapy.

explanation.intuition: NHL is like a family of diseases rather than one disease - from slowly growing 'weeds' (indolent lymphomas) that may not need treatment, to rapidly spreading 'wildfires' (aggressive lymphomas) requiring urgent treatment. Paradoxically, some indolent lymphomas are incurable but patients live decades, while aggressive lymphomas are often curable with intensive therapy.
explanation.key_insight: The indolent-aggressive distinction is critical: Indolent lymphomas (follicular, marginal zone) are rarely curable but compatible with long survival; aggressive lymphomas (DLBCL, Burkitt) are rapidly fatal if untreated but often curable with chemotherapy. Treatment approach is completely different.
explanation.technical_details: WHO classification is based on morphology, immunophenotype, genetics, and clinical features. DLBCL is classified by cell-of-origin (germinal center B-cell vs activated B-cell) with different prognosis and emerging targeted therapies. Follicular lymphoma has t(14;18) BCL2 translocation. Burkitt has t(8;14) MYC translocation with 100% proliferation rate.

definitions_glossary.indolent_lymphoma: Slow-growing lymphoma; often incurable but long survival possible
definitions_glossary.aggressive_lymphoma: Rapidly growing lymphoma; fatal if untreated but often curable
definitions_glossary.DLBCL: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma; most common aggressive NHL (~30% of NHL)
definitions_glossary.follicular_lymphoma: Most common indolent NHL; t(14;18) BCL2 rearrangement
definitions_glossary.Burkitt_lymphoma: Highly aggressive NHL with t(8;14) MYC; endemic (EBV), sporadic, HIV-associated
definitions_glossary.mantle_cell_lymphoma: Aggressive B-cell lymphoma; t(11;14) cyclin D1; CD5+
definitions_glossary.marginal_zone_lymphoma: Indolent B-cell lymphoma; MALT, splenic, nodal subtypes
definitions_glossary.R_CHOP: Standard regimen for DLBCL: rituximab + cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, prednisone
definitions_glossary.IPI: International Prognostic Index for aggressive lymphoma
definitions_glossary.FLIPI: Follicular Lymphoma IPI for indolent lymphoma
definitions_glossary.transformation: Conversion of indolent to aggressive lymphoma (e.g., FL to DLBCL)
definitions_glossary.double_hit_lymphoma: DLBCL with MYC and BCL2/BCL6 rearrangements; very aggressive

pathophysiology.cell_of_origin: B cells (85%), T cells (15%), NK cells (<1%)
pathophysiology.mechanism: Accumulation of genetic alterations in lymphoid cells at various stages of development
pathophysiology.spread_pattern: Noncontiguous (unlike Hodgkin lymphoma); often widespread at diagnosis

aggressive: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) - most common

mature_T_cell_and_NK_cell_neoplasms: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALK+ and ALK-)

common_features: Painless lymphadenopathy (may be rapidly enlarging in aggressive NHL)
Extranodal involvement more common than HL (GI, skin, CNS, bone)
B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss)

subtype_specific.DLBCL: Rapidly enlarging mass, often extranodal (GI, CNS)
subtype_specific.Burkitt: Jaw mass (endemic), abdominal mass (sporadic), tumor lysis syndrome risk
subtype_specific.mantle_cell: Elderly males, GI polyposis, aggressive course
subtype_specific.MALT: Extranodal sites (stomach H. pylori, ocular, lung, salivary)

staging.Ann_Arbor_with_Lugano_modification: Same as HL but extranodal involvement more common
workup: PET-CT for FDG-avid subtypes (DLBCL, FL, HL)
LP for CNS-prone subtypes (Burkitt, testicular DLBCL, high IPI)

IPI_for_DLBCL.interpretation: 0-1 low risk; 2 low-intermediate; 3 high-intermediate; 4-5 high risk

DLBCL.standard: R-CHOP × 6 cycles (+ radiation for bulky disease)

aggressive_NHL.Burkitt: Intensive regimens (CODOX-M/IVAC, hyper-CVAD); CNS prophylaxis essential
aggressive_NHL.mantle_cell: Intensive induction → auto-HSCT consolidation; BTK inhibitors for relapsed

indolent_NHL.asymptomatic: Watch-and-wait (observation); treatment does not improve survival
indolent_NHL.gastric_MALT: H. pylori eradication; radiation if H. pylori negative

novel_therapies.CAR_T: Tisagenlecleucel, axicabtagene ciloleucel for relapsed DLBCL
novel_therapies.targeted: BTK inhibitors (mantle cell), PI3K inhibitors (follicular), EZH2 inhibitors (FL)

definition.@value: A heterogeneous group of lymphoid neoplasms arising from B, T, or NK cells, encompassing over 60 subtypes ranging from indolent to highly aggressive, classified by WHO criteria and treated according to subtype-specific biology

scopeNote.@value: Excludes Hodgkin lymphoma; includes all other lymphoid malignancies

learning_objectives: Classify NHL by cell of origin and clinical behavior (indolent vs aggressive)
Describe the major NHL subtypes and their characteristic features
Apply IPI and FLIPI prognostic indices
Compare treatment approaches for indolent vs aggressive NHL
Identify indications for CAR-T and other novel therapies
clinical_pearls: DLBCL is most common aggressive NHL; follicular is most common indolent
Watch-and-wait is appropriate for asymptomatic indolent NHL
Burkitt lymphoma has 100% proliferation index (Ki-67); needs urgent treatment
Double-hit lymphoma (MYC + BCL2) requires intensified therapy
Gastric MALT may regress with H. pylori treatment alone
CAR-T has transformed relapsed DLBCL prognosis (40% durable remissions)
common_misconceptions: NHL is one disease - it's >60 distinct entities
Indolent lymphoma is 'better' - it's incurable, just slow-growing
All NHL needs treatment - asymptomatic indolent NHL may be observed for years
